text: Fig. 1 shows the powder X-ray diffraction pattern for BFOQ (quenched) sample collected using lab X-ray source. The inset of the figure shows the magnified portion of 2θ position where the most intense peak of Bi25FeO40 (sillenite peak) is expected. From the X-ray diffraction pattern, shown in Fig. 1, it was found that this sample contains ∼1% wt fraction of Bi25FeO40 as an impurity phase. In order to get the finer details about the structure of the prepared samples; the obtained powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the prepared samples were analyzed using FullProf Rietveld refinement program . BiFeO3 is known to have rhombohedral crystal structure with a space group of R3c, where bismuth (Bi) and iron (Fe) atoms are located at 6b position (0, 0, 0) and (0, 0, z) respectively and oxygen (O) atoms are located at 18b position (x,y,z) . Fig. 2 (a) and (b) shows the refined X-ray diffraction pattern for BFOQ (quenched) and BFOS (post annealed/sintered) samples respectively. It should be noted from Fig. 2(b) that BFOS sample also contain ∼1% wt fraction of Bi25FeO40 as an impurity phase. Thus, the chemical phase composition in prepared sample appears to be unchanged after sintering/heat treatment as observed from lab source diffraction data. The parameters obtained from the refinement for both the samples are given in Table 1 . A good agreement between the observed and calculated pattern can be observed. The goodness of fit ‘S’ which is defined as the ratio of weighted pattern (Rwp) and the expected pattern (Rexp), given in Table 1 is better for BFOS as compared to BFOQ sample. This indicates that the structural quality of BFOS is better than BFOQ sample. An X-ray density (as given in Table 1) of ∼8.33 gm/cm3, is obtained for both the samples, which is comparable to the theoretical chemical density .

Fig. 3d shows the room temperature PL spectra (excited at 330 nm) for pure BFO and N-BFO. All samples possess the strong PL peaks centering at 425 nm. It was observed from the PL spectra that the pure BFO displayed a strong PL intensity, meaning the high recombination of charge carriers in pure BFO. After introducing the N dopants in the BFO, the PL intensity of the N-BFO decreased with the increasing amounts of N (2.5 and 5 mmol), indicating that the recombination of photogenerated e−-h+ pairs is efficiently hampered. At low doping concentration, defect states are generated in the band gap below the conduction band edge and above the valence band edge, which can behave as trapping centers of electrons and holes [41], leading to a low charge recombination rate. However, PL intensity of the N-BFO was increased drastically with the further increase in N content from 12.5 mmol to 35 mmol. This could be ascribed to the fact that the excessive N doping in BFO could result in an increase of lattice defects, which act as the recombination center of photo-generated e−-h+ pairs [42]. Based on the PL results, the intensity of 5N-BFO and 12.5N-BFO is weaker than that of pure BFO and other N-BFO, meaning the better separation of photogenerated charge carriers, these are highly beneficial for photocatalytic applications.

Figure 1 shows the XRD patterns of BFO and BLFO nanoparticles prepared by sol–gel (Fig. 1a and b) and hydrothermal (Fig. 1c and d) methods. The recorded diffracted planes match well with the standard card of bismuth ferrite (JCPDS card No. 86-1518) and XRD patterns confirm the single perovskite phase of BiFeO3 with distorted rhombohedral structure (R3c). All patterns show strong and sharp diffraction peaks which indicate well crystallinity of all as-prepared particles. For pure BFO samples a few weak diffraction peaks related to the impurity phases like Bi2Fe4O9 and Bi25FeO40 are observed. However, when the La3+ is substituted into the BFO structure, for the SGBLFO sample, the impurity phases disappeared (Fig. 1a) and coincidently, two major peaks around 2θ ~ 32° starts to merge into the one peak (Fig. 1b). This change is due to a phase transformation from rhombohedral to monoclinic structure. On the contrary, for HTBLFO sample, the impurity phases is still observed and merging of two peaks around 2θ ~ 32° is not happened and no structural phase transition is occurred (Fig. 1c and d). This discrepancy between SGBLFO and HTBLFO can be explained by existence of impurity phases.

Fig. 1 (a) shows the room temperature experimental and simulated XRD patterns of BFO nanoparticles. All the diffraction peaks can be indexed using JCPDS Card No. 86–1518, which suggest that BFO has rhombohedral perovskite structure with R3c space group. The peaks related to any other phase are not observed in the detection limit of XRD, which indicates the formation of phase pure BFO. The simulated XRD pattern, using Rietveld refinement program FULLPROF, indicates that best fit to the experimental data is observed using rhombohedral lattice type with space group R3c. This structural model allowed us to reproduce all the observed reflections. The structural parameters obtained from the Rietveld refinement of the X-ray pattern (listed in Table 1 ) confirms the quality of the agreement between calculated and observed diffraction pattern. The average crystallite size is calculated by using Scherrer formula from the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the XRD peaks after removing instrumental broadening and is found to be ∼25 nm, which indicates nanocrystalline nature of BFO. After taking strain into account due to nanocrystalline nature, the effective crystallite size is estimated using Williamson-Hall Method and is found to be ∼35 nm [30]. Fig. 1b shows wide range XPSspectrum of BFO nanoparticles. This shows a series of sharp peaks resulting from direct excitation of electrons from the core levels. The Bi 4f, Bi 4d, and O ls peaks are prominent while Bi 4p and Fe 2p peaks are less intense, indicating the existence of Bi, Fe, and O elements in the BFO nanoparticles. The observed C element in this spectrum is probably due to the surface contamination in air. Fig. 1c shows narrow-scan XPS spectrum for Bi 4f from the BFO nanoparticles. The 7/2 and 5/2 spin-orbit doublet components of the Bi 4f photoemission located at the binding energies of 158.8 and 164.2 eV, respectively, are the characteristics of Bi3+. Fig. 1d shows the narrow-scan XPS spectrum of Fe 2p from the BFO nanoparticles, in which the 3/2 and 1/2 spin-orbit doublet components of the Fe 2p photoemission are observed at 710.8 and 724.2 eV, respectively, are the characteristic for Fe3+ and agree well with the literature data [32]. Moreover, a satellite peak is always associated at 6.0 or 8.0 eV above 2p3/2 principal peaks of Fe2+ and Fe3+, respectively, due to different d-orbital electron configurations of Fe2+ and Fe3+ and are found to be important for identifying the chemical states [32]. Therefore, the presence of satellite peak at 718.8 eV (as shown in Fig. 1d), about 8.0 eV above the Fe 2p3/2 peak, confirms the Fe3+ valence state. No XPS peaks due to Fe2+ ions and Fe are detected. The present XPS results show that BFO nanoparticles has a single phase with Bi3+ and Fe3+ valence state and consistent with the XRD result. Fig. 1e shows the MS spectra of BFO nanoparticles collected at room temperature. The magnetic hyperfine splitting spectra indicate that the sample is in magnetically ordered state and Néel temperature (TN) of BFO nanoparticles is above room temperature. It is evident from the MS spectra that the width of spectral lines is not same, especially for outer lines. This asymmetric line broadening is due to a continuous distribution of hyperfine parameters. It has been reported that in BFO the asymmetry in spectra is due to its modulated spiral spin structure. The spectrum can be fitted by two Zeeman sextets with hyperfine fields of H1 = 50.3 T and H2 = 48.8 T and isomer shifts of δ 1 = 0.38 mm/s and δ 2 = 0.37 mm/s. These values are typical of high-spin Fe3+. This indicates that Fe3+ ion is present in two different crystallographic environments that differ primarily in the size of the electric field gradient. No signal of Fe2+ is detected from our spectroscopic data.

The X-ray powder diffraction patterns of the Bi1− xSrxFeO3 (x = 0.0, 0.15, 0.175, 0.25) samples (abbreviated as BFO, BSFO-15, BSFO-175 and BSFO-25 respectively) are shown in Fig. 1 . From the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern, it is observed that pristine BFO sample crystallizes in distorted rhombohedral structure with R3c space group where all the diffraction peaks matches well with the standard crystal data corresponding to the JCPDS file No. 86-1518, except a minor low-intensity impurity peak around 2θ = 28.42° associated with Bi2Fe4O9. This observed impurity peak matches well with the JCPDS file No. 72-1832.

Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of various Bi1-xBaxFeO3 (x = 0, 0.05, 0.1, and 0.2 mol%) MNPs. The pure BFO MNPs showed a perovskite rhombohedral structure as reported previously , and no secondary phase was detected by XRD analysis.

The structure and phase purity of the samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using Cu-Kα radiation at room temperature. The morphology and local element occupancy were examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL-6380LV, Japan) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, HORIBA EMAX Energy EX-250). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging and grain size characterization were performed on a JEOL JEM-2100 microscope, by depositing a drop of sample dispersion onto a 300 mesh Cu grid coated with a carbon layer. Ferroelectric hysteresis loops (P–E) and leakage current density–electric field (J–E) curves were measured using a Radiant precision materials analyzer, with each powder sample pressed into a thin piece under a pressure of 20 MPa and having an area of around 0.2 cm2 and a thickness of around 0.08 cm. Ag electrodes were coated on both sides. Magnetization hysteresis (M–H) loops were evaluated at room temperature up to a field of 50 kOe using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM).

Figure 1 shows the XRD 2θ–θ patterns of BFO and Cu, Zn, Mn 2 at% substitution BFO thin films prepared on ITO/glass substrates. It indicates that all the detectable diffraction peaks for the all thin films match well to the distorted perovskite R3c structure. No impurity phases can be observed in all samples. There was no significant structural change in the transition metals (Cu, Zn and Mn) doped BFO thin films compared with the pure BFO thin film. But it is worth noting that the (012) and (104)/(110) diffraction peaks of Zn doped BFO thin film was stronger than those of others. In contrast, Mn doped BFO thin film has the lowest (012) and (104)/(110) diffraction peaks. The average grain size (D) of the samples are estimated based on Scherrer’s Eq.:

The analysis of X-ray diffraction of the BiFeO3 ceramics showed that the sample preserves the rhombohedral structure (space group R3c) in the wide temperature range from 300 K up to 900 K. The results obtained are in agreement with literature data . The X-ray pattern of BFO obtained at room temperature is shown in Fig. 9. In addition to the main phase, traces of impurities are observed (indicated by asterisks in Fig. 9). This impurity has been identified as Bi2O3. The content of this precipitation is about 4%, estimated from the formula c=Iprec/(Iprec+IBFO) where I prec and I BFO denote the most intensive lines assigned to the precipitation phase and to the main phase, respectively. The relative volume expansion of the cell within the temperature range 300–900 K estimated as (ΔV/V 0)×100%≈2% is relatively small. One can see in Fig. 10 that the increase in the lattice parameter a is insignificant since the relative expansion (Δa/a 0)×100%≈0.08%, while the lattice constant c changes markedly by (Δc/c 0)×100%≈0.8 It means that with increasing temperature the unit cell grows up predominantly along the c-direction. No abrupt changes in the lattice parameters were observed. However, one can distinguish a slight change in the rate of temperature changes of the crystal lattice parameter c in the vicinity of AFM–PM phase transition.

Raman spectroscopy enables information regarding local structures within materials to be obtained. The Raman spectra of pure BFO and Ba-doped BFO MNPs are shown in Fig. 6 . To determine the effect of Ba-doping on BFO structure, the observed Raman modes of Ba-doped BFO MNPs were compared with that of pure BFO MNPs. BFO belongs to the R3c space group and the C3v point group. The irreducible representations obtained from group theory are as follows: 4A1 (z, x2 + y 2, z2) + 5A2 (−) + 9E (x, y, x2 − y 2, xy, xz, yz) . The A1 and E modes are both IR- and Raman-active, whereas the A2 modes are IR-active only. Four A1 modes pervade along the c-axis while nine E modes (double-degenerated) pervade in the x–y plane . These involve A1-1, A1-2 and A1-3 modes with strong scattering intensity, A1-4 mode with very weak scattering intensity and nine E modes with medium scattering intensity . However, the resonance frequency is different from that previously reported in various studies due to the different sample characteristics and measurement methods . In this research, as shown in Fig. 6, we observed three strong peaks near 136, 168, and 220 cm−1, a weak peak at 439 cm−1 relative to A1 modes and 9E Raman modes with the strongest intensity at about 95 cm−1 for pure BFO MNPs in the frequency range below 700 cm−1. With substitution concentration of 0.05 mol%, the first two A1 modes at 136 and 168 cm−1 would be merged together and some of Raman peaks below 250 cm−1 shifted to higher frequency. For example, the E1 mode at 99 cm−1 moved toward a higher frequency of 104 cm−1. A new strong peak around 313 cm−1 seemed to be created because of the shifting of the two modes of E-3 and E-4 centered at 270 cm−1 to the higher frequency, 313 cm−1. This behavior may be related to the structural distortion from rhombohedral to tetragonal, as reported previously . This study also identified the structural disorder which was confirmed by the evidence observed at a high peak intensity of 313 cm−1 at x = 0.05 mol%. As shown in Fig. 6, increasing the doping to x = 0.1 and 0.2 mol% resulted in structural disorder, however, with reduced peak intensity at 313 cm−1.

The thermal stability of as-prepared nanoparticles is shown in Fig. 8. In a case of calcination at 650 °C, the initial weight loss of 0.30% occurred from 0 to 220 °C, this can be attributed to the loss of moisture, H2O, etc., from the surface of nanoparticles. On further increasing the temperature from 227 to 356 °C, weight loss observed was 0.40%, which proved that reaction start occurring that leads to the formation of Bismuth ferrite (BiFeO3) nanoparticles. A very small weight loss was also observed in the range of 356–550 °C, this may be attributed due to the decomposition of organic impurities before 550 °C. The weight loss above 550 °C was attributed due to the decomposition of nitrate species. With increasing the calcination temperature the stability increases as weight percentage left for the samples calcinated at 150, 450, 550 650 and 750 °C was 87.4, 97.9, 98.8, 99.01 and 98.7, respectively. The reason for higher weight percentage left with increasing temperature from 150 to 650 °C could be attributed to the formation of stable single phase of Bismuth ferrite (BiFeO3) nanoparticles as proved earlier by XRD results. But at 750 °C, percentage amount left was decreased from 99.01 for 650 °C to 98.7; this might be due to the formation of various impurity phases.

In this work, rGO was grown on the positively charged BiFeO3 through electrostatic reaction. As seen from Fig. 1D, the zeta potentials of GO and BiFeO3 nanoparticles were −36.0 mV (curve 'c') and +25.2 mV (curve 'a'), respectively, which provided an important precondition for the electrostatically formation of GO-BiFeO3 composite. After formation of rGO-BiFeO3 nanohybrids, the zeta potential was +6.9 mV (curve 'b'), which was attributed to the presence of small-amount rGO in the nanohybrids. Logically, one question arises as to whether graphene oxide was reduced to the rGO. To confirm the successful reduction of GO to rGO during the hydrothermal process, Raman spectroscopy was applied to investigate these samples. As indicated in Fig. 1E, two prominent peaks assigning to D (1353 cm−1) and G (1610 cm−1) bands of the rGO were clearly observed in the rGO-BiFeO3 nanohybrids (curve 'b'). The ID/IG value (1.08) obviously increased in comparison with that of GO (0.92) (curve 'c'), suggesting the reduction of GO to rGO in the nanohybrids (). Meanwhile, both BiFeO3 (curve 'a') and rGO-BiFeO3 nanohybrids exhibited distinct peaks at 136, 169, 216, 260, 342 and 469 cm−1 assigning to A1-1, A1-2, A1-3, E-2, E-3 and E-5, respectively, which agreed well with previous reports for BiFeO3 (). Next, the crystal structures of BiFeO3 nanoparticles before and after modification with rGO were determined using X-ray diffraction (XRD). As displayed in Fig. 1F, both XRD patterns showed clear and identical peaks indexing to rhombohedral perovskite structure of BiFeO3 (JCPDS No. 86–1518), while no other phases such as Bi2Fe4O9 or Fe2O3/Bi2O3 were found, indicating high purity of the obtained samples. Moreover, no obvious diffraction peaks of rGO were observed from the XRD pattern due to small amount of rGO (~ 2.0 wt%) in rGO-BiFeO3 nanohybrids. The maintained crystal phase of BiFeO3 in the nanohybrids provided an important condition for the construction of rGO-BiFeO3 based PEC sensing system. Based on these results mentioned above, we confirmed the successful synthesis of rGO-BiFeO3 nanohybrids.

Fig. 1 shows the room-temperature XRD data obtained for the SPS synthesized ceramic samples of the Bi1−xTbxFeO3 solid solution system for Tb concentrations within the range of 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.30. The peak intensity ratios in the presented diffractograms are indicative of ceramics with good crystallinity. At first sight, by comparing the stacked XRD patterns in Fig. 1a, one can spot an apparent change in diffraction profiles for different Tb contents, involving a shift of peak positions, an increase in the peak width and the disappearance of some parental peaks along with the appearance of new peaks upon progressive Tb substitution. The shifting of peaks towards higher 2θ angles (see the enlarged views of the XRD patterns for selected 2θ ranges, Fig. 1b and c) with increasing Tb doping content indicates a reduction in d-spacing which is directly related to the unit cell shrinkage. The broadening of peaks may possibly originate from a decrease in grain size, which is promoted by Tb addition. SEM micrographs in the insets of Fig. S1 (in the ESI†) clearly demonstrate the inhibiting effect of Tb substitution on grain growth in the microstructure of the ceramics. Muneeswaran et al. have shown using the XRD and TEM methods that the crystallite size decreases alongside the particle size with increasing Tb content in BiFeO3 nanoparticles. An agreement between the size of the particles, as determined from TEM, and that of the crystallites, as estimated from XRD peak broadening, was obtained for the Bi1−xTbxFeO3 ceramic series. Our calculations, using the Debye–Scherrer formula on the measured XRD data, confirm that the average crystallite size decreases upon terbium substitution. The estimated size of crystallites of the pure BiFeO3 ceramics was found to be 70–80 nm, while the broadening of the XRD peaks of the x ≥ 0.20 samples indicates that the highly doped ceramics are composed of 40–50 nm crystallites. Similar trends in decreasing both the grain size and the crystallite size upon A-site rare earth substitution were reported for Dy-doped BiFeO3 ceramics. Besides the observed right shift in 2θ positions and peak broadening, the reflections associated with the pure BiFeO3 phase show a continuous decrease in intensity as the concentration level of Tb increases. Ultimately, for the x = 0.30 ceramic, the two most intense peaks around 2θ ≈ 32° (Fig. 1c), as well as the prominent peak at 2θ ≈ 38° of pure BiFeO3 disappear completely. On the other hand, there is a distinct peak at 2θ ≈ 25° in the XRD patterns of the samples with x ≥ 0.15 which cannot be observed in pure BiFeO3. Such a development in diffraction characteristics indicates a substantial structural modification in the SPS synthesized Tb-doped BiFeO3 ceramics.

Figure 1 displays the room temperature XRD patterns of composites xNi0.75Zn0.25Fe2O4–(1 − x)BiFeO3 (for x variations 0.10, 0.20, and 0.30) along with the individual phases of NZF and BFO. The presence of mixed spinel-perovskite phase is clearly shown in the XRD pattern of composites with x = 0.10, 0.20, and 0.30. The pure phase of BiFeO3 is difficult to obtain due to kinematics of formation. Small amount of impurity phases like Bi2Fe4O9 and Bi36Fe24O57 (marked as •) is observed along with the majority phase of BiFeO3 which are commonly observed in this system. The indexing of the diffraction peaks of the composites complies with the reported values for NZF and for BFO, the pattern agreed with JCPDS card No. 71-2494. NZF stabilizes in cubic spinel structure with lattice parameter a = 8.345 Å, and BFO exhibits rhombohedral structure having lattice parameters a = 5.557 Å and c = 13.752 Å. There is slight variation in lattice parameters corresponding to BFO and NZF phases in composites due to change in positions of diffraction peaks corresponding to both phases, which indicates the structural distortion in the composites. The crystallite size (Dm) has been estimated for NZF phase from the reflection line (311) using the Scherrer’s equation: Dm = Kλ/cos θ where K is constant, λ is the wavelength of X-rays used, is full width half maxima, and θ is the diffraction (Bragg) angle. The crystallite sizes for NZF phase in composites and lattice parameters calculated for the individual phases in the composites with x = 0, 0.10, 0.20, 0.30, and 1.0 are summarized in Table 1. With increase of NZF content, the intensity of the peaks corresponding to NZF phase is enhanced. Moreover, it can be seen from Table 1 that the crystallite size is found to increase with increase of NZF content.

Figure 1 shows XRD pattern of BiFeO3 powders synthesized with 4 M NaOH at 110–130 °C for 14 h. It is found when 110 °C is employed, the BiFeO3 phase with a perovskite structure is acquired, companying the formation of a certain amount of Bi2Fe4O9 phase. Moreover, with an increase of the reaction temperature, Bi2Fe4O9 phase gradually decreases while BiFeO3 phase greatly increases. When reaction temperature increases to 130 °C, it is found all diffraction peaks of the product prepared by the present method can be indexed to perovskite (space group R3c) BiFeO3 and no other peaks from other phases are detected. Moreover, the sharp diffraction peaks reveal that the single-phase BiFeO3 powders have good crystallinity and exhibit rhombohedrally distorted perovskite structure. The pure BiFeO3 sample hydrothermally synthesized at 130 °C is denoted as BFO-HT.

Rietveld fitted X-ray diffraction patterns for sintered BFO, CFO and BFO-CFO composites are shown in Fig. 1 (a–e). XRD pattern of pure BFO is indexed rhombohedral phase (R3c) (ICDD file no. 71–2494) while of CFO is matched with inverse spinel (Fd3¯m) cubic phase (ICDD file no. 22–1089) without any traces of impurities. BFO and CFO retained their respective structure and phase in composite form along with minor impurity phase [Bi2Fe4O9 – marked with asterisk (*)]. It might be occurred due to Bi-volatilization and oxygen off stoichiometry during sintering [,]. Phase analysis shows perovskite-spinel mixed structure. In addition to that, peak corresponds to spinel phase along (311) direction appears stronger with the increasing concentration of CFO in composites. This is clear evidence of formation of perovskite-spinel mixed structure. Magnified view of reflection peak (012) [see Fig. 1(f)] shows significant shift towards lower bragg's angle for composites. This concludes an occurrence of strain due to CFO in BFO matrix [,]. Higher percentage of CFO causes more strain in composites which is responsible for higher shift in XRD peaks. Refined lattice parameters are a = b = 5.5752(3) Å and c = 13.8601(9) Å for sintered BFO and a = b = c = 8.3810(5) Å for sintered CFO are comparable with earlier reports [,]. XRD patterns of composites are refined with combination of two phases, rhombohedral (R3c) of BFO and cubic spinel (Fd3¯m) of CFO [Fig. 1(c), (d) and (e)]. Observed and simulated data is well matched and found lowered goodness of fit (GOF) values. Output structural parameters obtained after Rietveld refinement are tabulated in Table 2 . Phase fraction for composites is extracted out after refinement and shown in Table 3 (a). Obtained phase fractions have shown good agreement with initially taken fractions. XRD results confirm the composite formation with proper interaction of BFO and CFO phases at interfaces.

The preparation of pure single-phased BiFeO3 is one of the main issues of this compound caused by the narrow interval of its thermal stability and formation of secondary phases  ;   . However, in the past years many synthesis and characterizations of single crystals and nanopowders have been performed by the same authors ;  ;   . The chemical compounds used in this work were bismuth nitrate (Bi(NO3)3x5H2O), iron nitrate (Fe(NO3)3x9H2O), and potassium hydroxide (KOH) and all the chemicals were of analytical grade. The applied synthesis route was proposed by Han . The equi-molar mixtures of Bi(NO3)3x5H2O and Fe(NO3)3x9H2O were dissolved in 40 mL of KOH. The molar ratio of the alkali mineralizer was adjusted by dissolving certain amounts of KOH pellets into distilled water.

Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of BFO nanoparticles synthesized via ultrasound and sol–gel methods. In Fig. 1a, the impurity of Bi2O3 was detected in the sample synthesized via sol–gel method but, under the similar conditions, pure BFO nanocrystals were synthesized via ultrasound (Fig. 1b). The reflection peaks of the sample prepared via ultrasound can be indexed as a single-phase perovskite structure belonging to the space group R3c, which is in good agreement with the literature data of JCPDS Card No. 86-1518. The calculated lattice parameters (a = b = 5.5774 Å and c = 13.8667 Å) are in agreement with rhombohedral BFO nanoparticles according to the reported data. It can be seen from Fig. 1b that the diffraction peaks become broader for BFO nanopowders prepared via ultrasound which is due to the smaller size of the particles. The average crystallite size obtained from the Debye–Scherrer formula was 37.12 nm and 81.43 nm for the samples prepared via ultrasound and sol–gel methods, respectively.

Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns for BiFeO3 immobilization on silica fiber at different calcination temperatures of 748 K, 773 K, 798 K, 823 K, 848 K, 873 K, and 923 K for 5 h, using a combined impregnation method with CNFs templates route. These temperatures were determined so as to confirm the phase identification and the optimal calcination temperature for this case. As for the samples calcinated at 748–773 K (Fig. 2a and b), it can be seen that both spectra showed pretty good peaks at 23°, 32°, 39°, 46°, 52°, 57°, which can be well indexed to a BiFeO3 phase, possessing a perovskite structure (JCPDS No. 20-0169). As the calcination temperature was increased above 773 K (Fig. 2c–e), we can see that the crystallinity of BiFeO3 was only slightly improved. However, the main BiFeO3 phase coexisted with some other minor impurity Bi2O2.33 phase (JCPDS No. 27-0051), which might be resulted from a phase decomposition of BiFeO3 at medium calcination temperatures. When the calcination temperature was further increased above 873 K (Fig. 2f and g), the main peaks do not correspond to the BiFeO3 phase, and Bi2O2.33 became the dominant phase, together with a Fe2O3 phase appeared (JCPDS No. 33-0664), indicating a further phase decomposition of BiFeO3 occurred. It is obvious that the phase composition of the as-prepared samples was strongly affected by the calcination temperature, indicating that the calcination temperature plays a very important role in BiFeO3 immobilization process. In addition, the results elucidate that among these adopted calcination temperatures, 773 K is sufficient to completely remove CNFs templates and tends to form a relatively pure phase of BiFeO3 with a sharp and well defined peaks. Thus, it can be concluded that 773 K is the optimum calcination temperature for this case. Note that the average crystallite size of the immobilized BiFeO3 calcinated at 773 K for 5 h calculated by the Scherrer equation was ca. 115 nm, and its specific surface areas was calculated to be ca. 5.66 m2 g −1.

m, P4mm, R3m, R3c and Cm crystal structures were fitted to the experimental pattern. The best agreement with experimental points was obtained for the R3c space group. In the crystal structure ions occupy: Bi/Pb(0,0,0) and Fe/Nb(0,0, zFe) which both are (6a) positions and oxygen atoms are placed in (xO, yO, zO) general position (18b) with respect to hexagonal settings. The obtained experimental and fitted patterns are presented in Fig. 1. The calculated unit cell parameters are summarized in Table 1 and are compared to the data for pure BiFeO3 and calculated, further in the paper, values. There is evidenced small additional reflex at approximately 29° which could indicate small amount of the secondary pyrochlore phase.

Phase analysis of pure BiFeO3 ceramics (Fig. 1a) showed that the major perovskite phase displays a pattern characteristic of a rhombohedrally distorted perovskite structure (R3c space group). The signature diffraction peaks match well with the standard crystallographic data reported for the rhombohedral BiFeO3 in the Crystallography Open Database under the COD file No. 4336776. Along with the main R3c perovskite phase, traces of a minor impurity phase of the Bi2Fe4O9-like structure (COD file #9008148) are detected as extra, low-intensity diffraction peaks around 2θ ≈ 28° and 33° in the XRD pattern. The Bi25FeO39 sillenite and Bi2Fe4O9 mullite phases have been reported in the literature as typical processing by-products of the solid-state synthesis of BiFeO3 owing to the peculiar kinetics of phase formation in the Bi2O3–Fe2O3 system. Upon Tb substitution, the small-intensity Bragg reflections of the secondary phase disappear, which implies that a partial replacement of Bi3+ ions for Tb3+ ions stabilizes the formation of the perovskite phase during the conventional solid state reaction, and so it substantially reduces the amount of impurities in the final polycrystalline product. Similar observations on substitution-enhanced phase purity were reported for La-, Dy- and Gd- doped BiFeO3 ceramics. The diffraction profile of highly doped samples (x ≥ 0.20) was found to coincide closely with that of orthorhombic TbFeO3 (COD file #1008090). A weak signature of the emerging Pnma-type structure can be discerned for Bi0.9Tb0.1FeO3, in which double peaks (101)/(020) and (202)/(040) as well as a new (111) orthorhombic peak appear along with the dominant rhombohedral phase peaks in the XRD pattern. The substitution-induced suppression of the parental R3c phase and creation of a new Pnma structure in the Bi1−xTbxFeO3 system clearly demonstrate the ion size effect. An introduction of small Tb3+ ions into BiFeO3 perovskite is expected to reduce the tolerance factor since the average A-site ionic radius is decreased. To relieve the substitution-induced lattice stress, an essential change in the lattice parameters and unit-cell proportions must occur upon Tb doping, leading to the observed structural transformation in the Bi1−xTbxFeO3 system.

The Rietveld-refined XRD patterns of all samples are shown in Fig. 1(a), which indicates that all main XRD diffraction peaks could be well fitted with the BFO rhombohedral distorted perovskite structure (space group R3c). The detailed refined structural parameters are listed in Table S1 (Table S1, ESI†). A few minor impurity phases of Bi2Fe4O9 appeared in the Bi0.95Na0.05FeO3 sample. The unit cell structure of BFO, considered as distorted perovskite with strongly distorted FeO6 octahedrons at normal conditions, is shown in Fig. 1(b). Structural parameters obtained from the Rietveld refined XRD patterns for the pure and doped samples are given in Table 1. For the pure BFO nanoparticles, the lattice parameters were a bit less than the values reported in the literature (a = 5.577 Å, c = 13.867 Å, V = 373.57 Å), but the bond angle of Fe–O–Fe is slightly larger than that (155.68°). For BFO, the octahedral tilt is about 11–14° around the polar [111] axis, with the directly related Fe–O–Fe angle. As the Na doping concentration increased, the bond angle of Fe–O–Fe also increased. This result illustrates that the FeO6 octahedral tilting behavior was modulated in Na-doped samples, and a similar result has also been reported in Li-doped BFO, Mn-doped BFO and pure BFO nanoparticles.

The XRD patterns of the BFS–BT–Mn–x ceramics sintered at 950 °C for 2 h are shown in Fig. 1. A pure perovskite phase can be observed in all the ceramics except for the composition of x = 8.0 with a small amount of non-magnetic impurities Bi2Fe4O9. From Fig. 1b, it can be seen that the BFS–BT–Mn–x ceramics undergo gradually a structural transformation from the rhombohedral to monoclinic phase with x increasing from 0 to 8.0, and thus a rhombohedral–monoclinic MPB is formed at x = 0.5–1.0. This is evidenced by the gradual change in the shape of the peaks near 39.0° and 45.5°. Similar to pure BFO, the ceramic with x = 0 possesses a rhombohedral symmetry. As x increases, the splitting of two diffraction peaks near 39° gradually becomes weak and merges into a single peak with x increasing from 0.0 to 1.0, and then splits into two peaks again with x further increasing from 2.0 to 8.0. Meanwhile, the (024) diffraction peak near 45.5° gradually splits into two peaks (021/220) with x increasing from 0 to 8.0. These suggest that the ceramics undergo the transformation from the rhombohedral to monoclinic phase with x increasing from 0 to 8.0. It has been reported that MnO2 can be converted into Mn2O3 at 650 °C (4MnO2 → 2Mn2O3 + O2↑), and the primary manganese ions are Mn3+ ions in the ceramics sintered at 960–990 °C. However, for Mn-modified BFO-based materials, there is a reaction that can restrain the conversion of Fe3+ into Fe2+ between Mn3+ and Fe2+: and the spontaneity of this redox reaction is governed by the positive value of oxidation–reduction potential (0.74 V). In the present work, all the samples were sintered at 950 °C; therefore, it can be reasonably inferred that the Mn ions exist in two valence states: Mn3+ with a radius of 0.645 Å and Mn2+ with a radius of 0.83 Å. The ionic radii of Mn2+ and Mn3+ are much lower than those of Bi3+ (1.03 Å) and Ba2+ (1.35 Å), but very close to those of Fe3+ (0.645 Å), Ti4+ (0.605 Å) and Sc3+ (0.745 Å). Therefore, according to the principles of crystal chemistry, Mn3+ and Mn2+ most likely enter the B-sites for randomly substituting Fe3+, Ti4+ and Sc3+ ions due to their similar ionic radius (Fe/Ti/Sc ions vs. Mn ions). It can be also seen that all the diffraction peaks shift continuously toward lower 2θ in the ceramics with x increasing from 0.0 to 8.0, which should be attributed to the lattice expansion caused by the substitution of larger Mn ions (Mn2+ ∼ 0.83 Å and Mn3+ ∼ 0.645 Å) for smaller B-site cations (Fe3+ ∼ 0.645 Å and Ti4+ ∼ 0.605 Å).

The room temperature XRD spectra obtained for undoped and Sm3+ doped ceramics are shown in Fig.␣1 . BiFeO3 is known to have a rhombohedrally distorted perovskite structure described by space group R3c at room temperature. In this structure, the Bi3+ ions occupy the cubo-octahedral positions and Fe3+ ions are present in octahedral coordination. The rhombohedral cell (having α ∼ 89.4°) is very close to the cubic cell. The cations are displaced from their center of symmetry along [1 1 1]p direction with anion sub lattice having distortion according to an a − a − a − tilt system. The FeO6 octahedra rotate in antiphase around this direction [20]. All the peaks in the XRD profiles of Bi1− xSmxFeO3 ceramics (x = 0.0, 0.05 and 0.1 having code BF0/SM0, SM5 and SM10) samples are clearly related to perovskite-structured phases. Foreign phases of Bi2Fe4O9 and Bi25FeO40 are detected in undoped and 5% Sm3+ doped BiFeO3 samples [21]. These secondary phases are routinely observed in metastable BiFeO3 ceramics due to its chemical kinetics of formation. A single phase BiFeO3 material (as shown in XRD data) is formed by doping 10% Samarium at A-site which indicates that the Sm3+ ions are incorporated very well in the BiFeO3 crystal structure. Pure polycrystalline BiFeO3 samples with rhombohedral structure have clearly separated (1 0 4) and (1 1 0) diffraction peaks around 32°. The existence of these splitted peaks in the prepared samples confirms the distorted R3c rhombohedral structure which is compatible with the earlier reports [22,23]. Due to smaller ionic radius of Sm3+ as compared with Bi3+, the peaks around 32° shifts toward higher diffraction angle. The addition of trivalent Sm in BiFeO3 does not lead to any structural transition up to 10% doping which can be possible at higher concentration as reported in previous investigations [13,24].

Figure 3 illustrates XRD profile pattern of the BFO and BBFOs samples sintered at 800 °C for 1 h. The diffraction pattern of the BFO sample can be ascribed to a rhombohedral structure having space group R3c according to JCPDS no. 86-1518. The most intense twin peaks in a diffraction pattern can be clearly seen around 2θ ~ 32°. Inset shows, the twin peaks are well separated and appeared at 2θ = 31.67° and 32.01°, and could be assigned (104) and (110), respectively. The sharp and intense diffraction peaks indicating good crystallinity of sintered BFO sample. Beside, the diffraction pattern also reveals weak peaks of secondary phases such as mullite and sellenite around 2θ ~ 27.43°. The weight percentage of the secondary phases has been mentioned in Table 2. Formation of weak secondary phases in a BFO sample could be due to: (1) impurity in precursors, (2) overwhelming of backward chemical reaction kinetics, i.e., ΔG > 0, where ΔG is the Gibbs free energy of the equilibrium reaction between BFO and secondary phases. As far as impurities in precursors are concerned, analytical grade chemicals have been used as precursors as well as necessary precautions have also been taken, in all experiments, to synthesize pure BFO samples. It is known that sintering temperature and time plays a crucial role to control the chemical reaction kinetics. In this article, we report inhibition of the backward chemical reaction and advancement of the forward chemical reaction by substituting Ba ions on Bi site of BFO sample. XRD investigations confirmed suppression of the secondary phases in the BBFOs samples. In contrast, minor secondary phases could not be suppressed in the Ba-substituted samples prepared by sol–gel method followed by heating at 550 °C for 2 h. The diffraction pattern of the BBFO1 sample (10% Ba2+ ions in BFO) reveals the twin peaks begin to merge into single peak, indicating a gradual transition from the distorted rhombohedral structure to pseudocubic structure. On 20% Ba2+ ion substitution in BFO (BBFO2), the twin peaks merged into a sharp and intense peak (110) suggest the structural transition from the distorted rhombohedral (R3c) to pseudocubic (Pm3m) is nearly completed. The phase transition from the perovskite distorted rhombohedral to tetragonal or orthorhombic or pseudocubic or binary phases mainly depends on synthesis method, sintering temperature and time, type of substitution ions and their concentration as well. At ambient conditions, generally, the phase transitions occur due to tilts of octahedra, and the endpoint of phase transition is a cubic (Pm3m) symmetry with no tilts. To investigate the effect of higher concentrations of Ba2+ ions on the structural change in a pure BFO sample, the ion concentration was increased to 30% but no further structural change in the cubic structure was noticed. By minute observations, a slight shift in the peak position towards lower Bragg angles is noticed, indicating an increase in the lattice parameters and hence an increase in the lattice volume. The peak shifts because of difference in the ionic radius of Ba ions (1.42 Å) and Bi ions (1.17 Å). Further, the effect of Ba2+ ion substitution on crystal degree of distortion of a perovskite from ideal cubic structure has also been examined by considering the tolerance factor relation:

In the earlier literatures, one of the reasons, for the presence of ferromagnetism in BFO samples has been attributed to the presence of parasitic Fe2O3 phase in the sample . The presence of Fe2O3 phase has not been observed in the present case for both the samples, as shown by the dashed lines in Fig. 10 (a) and (b). It should be noted that the peaks from Bi36Fe2O57 & Bi25FeO40 phases, are very close to peaks from Fe2O3 (d ∼2.71Å) phase and hence can be mistaken to be due to Fe2O3 phase. It can be noted that the peak at d-value ∼2.7Å, increases in BFOS sample i.e. with sintering. Had the ferromagnetism been observed in these samples due to the presence of parasitic Fe2O3 phase, then magnitude of ferromagnetism in both the samples would have been different. The observation of same type of hysteresis in both the samples having different impurity level suggests the absence of Fe2O3 in our samples. These observations explain the almost identical magnetic properties of both the samples. Another reason for the presence of weak ferromagnetism in bismuth ferrite is believed to arise from the ferroelectric domain walls . In the present investigation, it was found from the high resolution transmission electron picture 7 (a) that the grains in BFOQ sample are smaller than that in BFOS sample. This is because BFOQ sample is quenched and have not got sufficient time for its grains to grow, however, BFOS sample is slowly heated and also slowly cooled, and hence its grains are comparatively larger. It is expected that smaller grains will also have smaller ferroelectric domain and hence the contribution from the domain wall will be larger (smaller domains signify a high volume density of domain walls). Hence, in BFOQ sample, where the grain size is small, ferroelectric domains are also small and hence the contribution of domain wall will be comparatively larger than BFOS sample. Since the weak ferromagnetism is believed to arise also from domain walls , slightly large remnant magnetization in BFOQ sample could be explained on this basis. Small differences in the magnitude of remnant magnetization may also be attributed to the presence of Fe2+ ions in BFOS sample and its absence in BFOQ sample, although its (Fe2+) effect on magnetic properties is not clear . This issue needs to be addressed further. Another point to be noted here is that since the grain size in the BFOQ sample is relatively smaller, and hence have comparatively larger surface to volume ratio, it is expected to show spin-glass behavior confined to just the skin layer, as reported . However, this issue can be addressed in further studies, where more detailed temperature dependent magnetization measurements will be done. Hence, X-ray diffraction results obtained using synchrotron source and transmission electron microscopy study, explains our magnetization results. Further from above discussion it appears that the observation of weak ferromagnetism in the samples prepared by rapid liquid-phase sintering method is an intrinsic property of these samples.

From XRD pattern, the peaks of bismuth ferrite nanoparticles become visible at 450 °C. These peaks point out the growth of the crystalline bismuth ferrite structure. Below this temperature (450 °C) some impurity peaks such as Bi36Fe2O57 and Bi3Fe4O9 were identified at 2θ=29.39°, 25.69 ° and 34.12° was reported . The intensity of peaks were increased and impurity peaks vanished with enhancing the annealing temperature . The samples of bismuth ferrite which annealed in air at 450 °C, 550 °C, and 650 °C show the pure phase perovskite structure of bismuth ferrite (BiFeO3) without any impurity phases in Fig. 1. The sample which annealed (T>650 °C) temperature points out the growth of impurity phases such as Bi2O3 and Bi3Fe4O9. It was observed that annealing in an Oxygen environment was lead to better and larger crystalline size as compared to the sample annealed in the air as shown in Fig. 2. The Scherrer’s formula was used to calculate the average crystallite size from the XRD peak broadening. The Scherrer’s formula is. t=Kλβcosθ where t is the crystalline size, K is a constant (0.94), ʎ wavelength of the radiation source (1.59 Ȧ ), β full width at half maximum and θ is Bragg's angle. The average crystallite size was calculated from the air and Oxygen annealed sample peaks by Scherrer’s formula. The average crystallite size of bismuth ferrite nanomaterials were synthesized by simple chemical route and annealed at different temperature and atmospheres i.e., air and oxygen is summarized in table 1. It was observed that average crystallite size was increased as the temperature increases due to the formation of the cluster, the better stabilization and growth of the bismuth ferrite structure . It was observed that the crystallite size increased in the case of oxygen annealing and also increased as the annealing temperature increases in both cases. This variation is shown in Fig. 3.

Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of pure BFO and Pt/BFO samples. It can be seen that the pure BFO sample was well crystallized and that all the diffraction peaks could be indexed by a rhombohedral phase with the space group R3c (JCPDS no. 86-1518), indicating that single crystalline BFO phase could be obtained by the present hydrothermal process. The corresponding lattice parameters were a=0.5577 nm, b=0.5577 nm and c=1.3862 nm, respectively. It is also noted that no Pt crystalline phase was detected for the samples containing Pt and their diffraction patterns were similar to that of pure BFO. This indicates that the Pt loading process would not change the BFO crystal structure.

The XRD data showed that no impurity phase existed in the film after treatment at 600 °C. The amorphous gel film crystallized to a single phase perovskite with no formation of intermediate phases or unwanted second phases. The XRD coherent crystalline domain size L was calculated using the Δ(2θ) values of the {111} reflection and the equation: Δ(2θ) = 0.89λ/Lcosθ, where λ is the wavelength of the X-rays. The value of L after corrections for the CuKα doublet was ~ 12 nm. Fig. 1B shows the XRD pattern of a BiFeO3 film deposited using the same experimental conditions on silica optical glass substrate, which exhibits a somewhat lower degree of crystallinity.

Using the above optimized precursor recipe and homogenous gel film preparation process, phase-pure BFO films of 150 nm thick were prepared on (001)-LSMO buffered STO substrates. Fig. 10(a) shows the XRD pattern of as-prepared (001)-BFO/LSMO/STO thin film. BFO (00l) peaks are observed and no crystallographic misorientation nor secondary phase occur in the film. The AFM topographic scan shown in Fig. 10(b) confirms a smooth surface with no open pores or cracking. Cross-section EDS analysis (shown in ESI S7†) was performed across the entire film cross-section to map the A-site stoichiometry. On average, EDS analysis of the films showed that the films are deficient in bismuth. The Bi:Fe ratio varies from 43.2:56.8 to 46.5:53.5 for scans collected over 150 nm. However, we also note that this deficiency does not compromise the yield of smooth gel films or eventually the ferroelectric performance. The ratios obtained here are in agreement with the reports of Sawa et al. who found that slightly Bi-deficient films made via PLD had attractive resistive switching properties. However, it is notable that neither the physical features (such as roughness, secondary phases, etc.) nor electrical properties are severely compromised by this slight deficiency.

From the XRD patterns of the BFO and BFMO films as shown in Fig. 1, all the films show the polycrystalline perovskite structure. This indicates a single phase structure with no secondary phases in all films. Moreover, a drastic change in XRD patterns is observed that the intensity of (012) peak gradually increases as Mn dopants increase. Interestingly, the intensity of (012) peak is even significantly larger than the intensity of (110) peak in BiFe0.90Mn0.10O3 thin film and the latter is usually the strongest peak in BFO films. As Fe3+ ions (ionic radii ~0.645 Å) were replaced by the smaller Mn4+ ions (ionic radii ~0.53 Å), a large distortion of FeO6 oxygen octahedrons may occur. As a result, the rhombohedral structure in pure BFO film may distort gradually or collapse into a nearly-tetragonal structure. In particular, this structure transformation confirmed by the later Raman spectra plays an important role in enhancing the ferroelectric polarization of BFO film.

Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the un-doped and different content lanthanum-doped BiFeO3 nanoparticles. For un-doped BiFeO3, all the prominent diffraction peaks in these patterns can be readily indexed to perovskite rhombohedral structure (space group R3c), which is in good agreement with the BiFeO3 (JCPDS Card No. 20–0169). The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 22.371°, 31.716°, 32.088°, 39.468°, 45.734°, 51.255°, 56.884°, 57.043°, 66.972° correspond to crystal plane (101), (012), (110), (021), (202), (113), (122), (300), (220) of BiFeO3. Additionally, a small impurity phase is detected in the sample in the 2θ = 27.668°, 30.654°, 32.937°, 41.645° and 52.370°, which corresponds to Bi25FeO40 (JCPDS Card No. 46–0416). After lanthanum-doping, the dominant peaks corresponding to the diffraction peaks of BiFeO3 are retained and the intensity of impurity peaks decreases in case of lanthanum-doped samples.

The Rietveld refined XRD patterns of all samples are shown in Fig. 1. The diffraction peaks of BFO and BGF samples are indexed according to rhombohedral structure, while rhombohedral and orthorhombic phases co-exist for BGFTx=0.0–0.10 samples. The small amount of secondary phases such as Bi2Fe4O9 and Bi24Fe2O39 exist in BFO sample, however, they are completely suppressed for BGF and BGFTx=0.03–0.10 samples. The presence of such secondary phases does not have any contribution to ferroelectric and magnetic properties of BFO. The suppression in peak splitting behaviour of (104) and (110) reflections and enhancement in broadening of (110) reflection suggest that the grain growth is limited by Ti substitution and the rhombohedral distortion is reduced towards orthorhombic structure. Furthermore, the twin peaks observed around 40°, 52°, and 57° tend to form a broad peak with increasing Ti concentration confirming the substitution of Ti in BFO lattice. Interestingly, the diffraction peaks shift towards higher 2θ value, indicating that co-substitution generates compressive lattice distortion.

It should be noted that, increasing BZT content up to 10 %, trace amount of secondary impurity phase in γ-Bi2O3-structure marked with asterisk (*) was observed while remarkable amount was there when BZT content is 20 %. This observation is in agreement with the facts of BZT perovskite being thermodynamically metastable and BF–BZT–BT discontinuous solid solution. With decreasing BZT content and/or increasing BT content, this γ-Bi2O3-structured impurity phase is suppressed strongly, in agreement with those previous reports on chemical pressure adjusting thermodynamic stability of BiFeO3-based perovskites. Combined with observations on BF–BZT and BT–BZT binary systems, a schematic boundary for single perovskite phase is also drawn up by a dashed line in Fig. 1.

The XRD pattern of the as-prepared BiFeO3 powder is shown in Fig. 1. This pattern showed only the peaks corresponding to perovskite-type BiFeO3 (JCPDS File No. 20–169), which crystallizes in the rhombohedral system. The perovskite synthesized is in an essentially pure phase, as evidenced by its XRD. No peaks attributable to Bi2O3 and/or Fe2O3 and unreacted precursor materials were detectable. The mean particle size of BiFeO3 was calculated using the Scherrer equation, D = (0.89λ)/(β1/2cos θ), where λ is the wavelength for Cu kα radiation, β1/2 is the corrected full width at half maximum (FWHM) and θ is the Bragg angle. The crystallite size of the powder particles is calculated at about 42 nm. This value agreed well with SEM and TEM observations (vide infra).

Figure 2a shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of pure and samarium (Sm3+) doped Bismuth ferrite (Sm:BFO) films. The X-ray diffraction pattern for the pure BFO films crystallizes in rhombohedral structure (R3c) with a doublet peak at 31.75° and 32.06°. The absence of any secondary phases such as Fe2O3, Bi2O3, Bi2Fe4O9 and Bi24Fe2O39 indicates that the present experimental procedure adopted for preparing Sm:BFO films would be quite suitable for magneto-optic device fabrication purpose. The incorporation of Sm3+ ions into BFO lattice crystal structure can be attributed to the merging of the two intense diffraction peaks at 31.75° and 32.06° which corresponds to the lattice plane (104) and (110) merges and thus the peak shift appears at 32°. This peak shift occurs due to the structural distortion when doping of smaller ionic radius of Sm3+ (0.96 Å) is replaced with higher atomic radius Bi3+ (1.03 Å) ions which were also reported by several others. Rare-earth substitution did not affect the crystal orientation of the BFO films although the peaks have shifted towards higher angle. This suggests that the addition of rare-earth can either eliminate oxygen vacancies or avoid compositional fluctuations of Fe3+–Fe2+ oxidation state influencing the appearance of secondary phases. Further, the crystallite size of Sm:BFO films with x = 0.05 and x = 0.1 on glass substrate was estimated to be 28 and 26 nm respectively, using Scherrer formula (Eq. 1).$$D = \frac{k\lambda }{{\beta_{hkl} \cos \theta }}$$ (1)where D is the crystallite size, k is the shape factor, λ is the wavelength of CuKα radiation and βhkl is the instrument corrected integral breadth of the reflection (in radians) located at 2θ and θ is the angle of reflection (in degrees). The instrument corrected broadening βhkl corresponding to the chosen diffraction peak was estimated using Eq. 2. $$\beta_{hkl} = \left[ {\left( {\beta_{hkl} } \right)^{2}_{measured} - \left( {\beta_{hkl} } \right)^{2}_{instrumental} } \right]^{1/2}$$ (2)

For the Bi0.98La0.02Fe0.99Ti0.01O3 ceramics prepared with various purities of raw oxides as showed in Table 1, their phase structures were characterized on crushed powders of sintered pellets and bulk pellets by X-ray diffraction, among which the recorded patterns for the L2 and L2ImBT ceramics sintered at 890 °C for 2 h illustrated in Fig. 1. For comparison, XRD pattern recorded on BiFeO3 powder synthesized at 800 °C for 2 h with stoichiometric Bi2O3–Fe2O3 mixture was also presented in Fig. 1. As exemplified by Fig. 1, it was seen that, same as BiFeO3, Bi0.98La0.02Fe0.99Ti0.01O3 prepared with different purity of raw oxides is crystallized in rhombohedral phase and their diffraction peaks are indexed well in accordance with R3c space group. In hexagonal unit cell, the lattice parameters were calculated with those first-order diffraction peaks as aH = 5.570(1) Å and cH = 13.838(2) Å with primitive cell volume Vp = 62.0(1) Å3 for the L2 powder sample. From Fig. 1, trace secondary phases of Bi25FeO39 and Bi2Fe4O9 were observed coexisting with rhombohedral perovskite phase in the BiFeO3 sample prepared here, which is consistent with those previous reports of BiFeO3 prepared by including traditional sintering and rapid liquid phase sintering. In contrast, those secondary impurity phases were strongly suppressed when adding 1.0 % LaFeO3 and LaTiO3 into BiFeO3, as demonstrated by Fig. 1.

The XRD patterns of LiFePO4/C samples synthesized by two methods are shown in Fig. 1. It can be seen that the main phase of sample LFP-2 synthesized by improved solid state method can be identified as LiFePO4 with an ordered olivine structure indexed to orthorhombic Pnma (JCPDS card number: 83–2092). However, in addition to the olivine phase, there also exists FeP4 phase in sample LFP-1, which may be attributed to the poor mixing effect of sample LFP-1. Table I lists the lattice parameters of both samples. It can be seen that the lattice parameters of sample LFP-2 is more close to the standard value (a = 1.0329 nm, b = 0.6011 nm, c = 0.4699 nm, V = 0.29103 nm3). On the other hand, the peak intensity of sample LFP-2 is also higher than that of sample LFP-1. All the above implies higher crystallization degree and phase purity of sample LFP-2. Although both samples have a carbon content of about 3 wt%, there is no additional diffraction peaks associated with crystal modification by carbon, which indicates that the generated carbon is amorphous and its presence does not influence the olivine structure of LiFePO4.

To study the structure of the cathode material and the effect of surfactant, the XRD patterns of the samples prepared with and without Tween 40 are shown in Fig. 1. Both the diffraction peaks can be well-indexed to pure LiFePO4 with an orthorhombic Pnmb (JCPDS card no. 40–1499). No characteristic diffraction peak of residual crystallized carbon from pyrolysis of glucose or surfactant can be observed, possibly due to its low content. It suggests that LiFePO4 can also be obtained from reducing FeOOH by glucose without adding the surfactant. However, two tiny parasitic peaks indexed, respectively, to lithium pyrophosphate (Li4P2O7) and lithium iron pyrophosphate (LiFeP2O7) can be detected in the sample, which are considered as the intermediate products of LiFePO4. The reason may be the intermediate products (Li4P2O7 and LiFeP2O7) cease to change into the end-product because the precursor is not mixed evenly. However, with the dispersive action of surfactant in precursor, this problem is solved; the surfactant improves the converting traces of Fe3+ to Fe2+ without any influence on the crystallization property.

XRD pattern of the samples prepared with two different feeding sequences are shown in Fig. 1 . All of the diffraction peaks can be well indexed to pure LiFePO4 with an orthorhombic olivine structure (JCPDS card no. 83-2092). No impurities such as Li3PO4 and others, which often appear in the LiFePO4 product synthesized by traditional routes, are observed. All diffraction peaks are strong and narrow, indicating the high crystallinity of the LiFePO4 samples prepared by two different methods. Otherwise, the carbon is not detected because the residual carbon is amorphous.

X-ray powder diffraction patterns of LiFePO4 coated with 60 wt.% malonic acid after firing at (a) 773, (b) 873, (c) 973 K are shown in Fig. 1. All samples reveal a single-phase LiFePO4 with an ordered olivine structure indexed by orthorhombic Pnmb (JCPDS card no. 40-1499). No impure phases of Fe2O3 and Li3Fe2(PO4)3 were observed in the as-prepared LiFePO4. The diffraction peaks became slightly sharper with increasing temperature, implying an improvement in crystallinity. However, no crystalline or amorphous carbons were detected in the XRD patterns, because the formed carbon was too small or too thin on LiFePO4.

Fig. 1 compared the XRD patterns of the sample A, CNSs, and sample B. The sharp diffraction peaks of the sample A and sample B without any impurity phase indicate a highly crystalline, phase pure LiFePO4. All the diffractions of the sample A and sample B could be indexed on the basis of orthorhombic olivine-type structure with Pnma space group. The lattice parameters of the as-synthesized samples are listed in Table 1 . The obvious difference in the lattice constants of the different axes of the two samples was observed, which shows the lattice constant of sample A is smaller than sample B. The effect of the combination of PEG and CNSs results in a more desirable structure of the olivine composite. The (1 1 1) and (1 1 3) reflections corresponding to graphite-like phase are seen in the XRD pattern of CNSs, but it is not well crystallized. As shown in Fig. 1, they are not observed in the XRD pattern of sample A and sample B due to its poor crystallinity. Elemental analysis confirms that the carbon content in sample A and sample B is 17.7 wt% and 16.2 wt%. When the same amount of PEG as sample A is only used with the other conditions constant, the carbon content is about 0.19 wt%. In addition, TOC of sample A is also determined and the value is 133.272 mg kg-1, which is much smaller than the content of CNSs in the sample. From this point of view, the PEG carbon in sample A can be negligible.

Patterns of BFO films on glass and on silicon substrate annealed at 600 °C are shown in Fig. 2 . Owing to as-deposited films are in amorphous form, they are not given in Fig. 2. All measured and indexed XRD patterns point to the pure rhombohedral perovskite structure which is in good agreement with the powder data of ICDD Card number 72-2035 [19,20]. No peaks from other phase were detected. This indicates that a well-crystallized single phase of the BFO was obtained. From XRD pattern the lattice parameters and the average grain sizes of the BFO films were calculated. The average grain sizes of the BFO on silicon and glass wafers were found by Debye–Scherrer equations to be 34,50 and 30,00 nm, respectively. The interplanar distances were calculated and found to be 3,976 Å for the BFO on silicon and 3,980 Å for the BFO on glass.

Furthermore, the diffraction peaks of Sr2+ doped BSFO-15, BSFO-175 and BSFO-25 samples revealed pseudotetragonal structure (P4/mmm space group) are well matching with the earlier reported data [20]. It has been noticed that, all the peaks undergoes a shift in 2θ. The doubly splitted peaks as observed for pristine BFO at about 2θ (≈52° and 57°) becomes a single broadened peak for Sr doped BFO (please see inset of Fig. 1). This confirms a structural transformation and continual change of lattice constants from rhombohedral (R3c) to pseudotetragonal structure (P4/mmm). Furthermore, the intensity of impurity peak observed at 2θ = 28.42° was found to decrease continuously with Sr-doping leading to the fact that addition of Sr2+ at Bi-site is helpful in suppressing the secondary phase. Henceforth, the samples as prepared by sol–gel method have a single-phase rhombohedral (BFO) or pseudotetragonal (BSFO-15, BSFO-175 and BSFO-25) perovskite structure with all constituent components forming a solid solution rather than a mixture of Bi2O3, Fe2O3 or any other impurity phase except Bi2Fe4O9 observed in pure BFO.

The HR-XRD measurements confirm that our BFO films are epitaxially grown on the MAO (0 0 1) substrates. 2θ − θ scans of a 900 nm thick film in Fig. 1(a) show that the BFO film has only (0 0 l) peaks, without other recognizable impurity phases. The film exhibits a wide peak with the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of 0.38° in the rocking curve (normal ω-scan) of the (0 0 2) reflection, showing low crystalline quality compared to the films grown on STO substrates . The poor crystalline quality of the BFO film on the MAO substrate may reflect the intrinsic mismatch and substantial defects which occur between perovskite and spinel structures. The ϕ-scan of the BFO (1 0 1) reflection (Fig. 1(c)) shows a four-fold symmetry of the epitaxial film, identical to that of the MAO (2 0 2) peak (Fig. 1(b)), confirming the cube-on-cube epitaxial relationship: BFO (0 0 1) || MAO (0 0 1); BFO [1 0 0] || MAO [1 0 0]. Notations with pseudocubic unit cells similarly sized with STO are used to indicate the crystalline orientation of the films. Close inspection of the 2θ − θ scan (inset Fig. 1(a)) shows that the film's lattices constant (c’ = 3.948 Å) is 0.30% smaller than the bulk value. Note that c’ is the distance between 0 0 l planes along the direction normal to the films’ surface. The reduced out-of-plane lattice constant indicates in-plane tensile strain. In general, an epitaxial strain from lattice mismatch will relax as the film gets thicker. Considering the substantial thickness (900 nm) of the film, and the large amount of defects between perovskite and spinel structure , it is unlikely that the tensile epitaxial strain is caused by the lattice mismatch between BFO and MAO. The difference in the thermal expansion coefficients between the substrate and the film is a possible origin of the tensile strain.

Fig. 1 displays the XRD patterns of the as-prepared g-C3N4/BiFeO3 composite samples, pure BiFeO3, and g-C3N4 samples. The diffraction peaks of pure BiFeO3 sample are in good agreement with pure rhombohedral phase BiFeO3 (JCPDS 71-2494). The pure g-C3N4 sample has two distinct peaks at 27.46° and 13.01°, which can be indexed as (002) and (100) diffraction planes (JCPDS 87-1526). With the decrease of g-C3N4 content, the diffraction peaks of g-C3N4 gradually decrease in intensity, and when the g-C3N4 content was below 25 wt%, only BiFeO3 diffraction peaks were found in Fig. 1. The nondetection of g-C3N4 in sample may be due to the low concentration and well dispersion of g-C3N4 powders . Consequently, the as-prepared g-C3N4/BiFeO3 composite samples had two phases: g-C3N4 and BiFeO3.

Figure 2 exhibits the XRD patterns of Ag/BiFeO3 hybrid materials. From curve b to d in Fig. 2, we can see the four diffraction peaks at 38.1, 44.3, 64.2 and 77.5° which are, respectively, corresponding to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) crystalline planes of metallic Ag and are marked with “inverted filled triangle.” The positions of the four peaks are perfectly matched with cubic phase Ag (metallic Ag, JCPDS file: 65-2871). Moreover, the intensity of the four diffraction peaks increases with the growth of AgNO3 dosage. The curve a is the XRD pattern of pure phase BiFeO3 which was prepared at the temperature of 550 °C. The diffraction peaks of BFO marked with “inverted open triangle.” These results illustrate the formation of metallic Ag and BiFeO3 composites and the content of metallic Ag in composites increasing with the growth of AgNO3 dosage.

The XRD diffractogram shows a R3cH polycrystalline BiFeO3 pure phase, indexed with JCD188396 card, without any traces of the common spurious phases Bi25FeO39, Bi2Fe4O9 and iron oxides [14,15]. No significant amorphous phase signature can be detected in the diffractogram as expected considering the Fe-O and Bi2O3-Fe2O3 phase diagrams [13,16,17]

Fig. 1(a) shows the measured XRD patterns of Bi1-xNdxFeO3 (x=0, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15, and 0.20) ceramics. All diffraction peaks of BiFeO3 can be indexed by the rhombohedral R3c structure with lattice parameters a=b=5.567 Å, c=13.778 Å. All the doped samples exhibit a perovskite-based structure with no trace of other impurity phases. From the Fig. 1(b), it shows that the (104) and (110) diffraction peaks of Bi1-xNdxFeO3 overlap partially to form a broadened peak and shift slightly to a higher angle with increasing doping content. This merging and shifting of diffraction peaks reveals a continual change of crystal structure in BiFeO3 which attributes to the smaller ion radius of Nd3+. In order to further illuminate the change of structure, the measured XRD patterns of the Bi1-xNdxFeO3 were analyzed by Rietveld refinement.

Figure 3 shows the XRD patterns of precursor and its calcined samples. From Fig. 3a, the results show that the precursor was a mixture containing monoclinic FeC2O4·2H2O [PDF card 23-0293, space group I2/a(15)] and Bi2(C2O4)3 [PDF card 14-0717]. When the precursor was calcined at 200 °C for 1.5 h, the characteristic diffraction peaks of FeC2O4·2H2O and Bi2(C2O4)3 disappeared, and characteristic diffraction peaks of Bi2O3 appeared. When the precursor was calcined at 300 °C for 1.5 h, characteristic diffraction peaks of Bi2O3 became stronger. However, when the precursor was calcined over 400 °C, intensity of the characteristic diffraction peaks of Bi2O3 became weak, and intensity of the characteristic diffraction peaks of BiFeO3 became strong with increasing calcination temperature (Fig. 3b). When the precursor was calcined at 600 °C for 1.5 h, strong intensity and smoothed baseline, a wide and low diffraction pattern of the thermal decomposition product was observed. Except three weak characteristic diffraction peaks of orthorhombic Bi2Fe4O9, a characteristic diffraction peak of unknown impurity was observed; all other the diffraction peaks in the pattern of the sample obtained at 600 °C were in agreement with those of hexagonal BiFeO3 with space group R3c (161), lattice parameters: a = 0.5588 nm, b = 0.5588 nm, c = 1.3867 nm, α = β = 90°, γ = 120°, and density = 8.311 g cm−3, from PDF card 71-2494, which indicated that the sample obtained at 600 °C was hexagonal BiFeO3. Compared with other synthesis methods of BiFeO3, crystallization temperature and purity of hexagonal BiFeO3 obtained by thermal decomposition of oxalates in this paper had few differences. For example, Wu et al. synthesized rhombohedral BiFeO3 by thermal decomposition of carbonates precursor at 600 °C for 2 h; however, the weak part of characteristic diffraction peaks of Bi2O3 was still observed. Navarro et al. obtained rhombohedral BiFeO3 with a small amount of β-Bi2O3 and Bi2Fe4O9 phases by thermal decomposition of Bi[Fe(CN)6]·4H2O at 600 °C for 5 h. Carvalho and Tavares prepared BiFeO3 with 99.7 % molar of the BiFeO3 phase by thermal decomposition of precursor from the sol–gel combustion method at 600 °C, only 0.3 % molar impurity phase of Bi25FeO39 was observed.

Fig. 1 shows the diffraction patterns of thermally treated powders at temperatures between 600 and 850 °C. The formed perovskite must have a composition close to BiFeO3. At the lowest tested temperature (600 °C), a mixture of initial precursors and a perovskite-structured material was obtained. At 800 °C, the material is practically formed by the perovskite phase without any traces of a secondary phase identified as Bi2Fe4O9 (JCPDS 20-0836-marked with ⁎ in Fig. 1a), which is commonly observed in this system . The formation of Bi2Fe4O9 by Bi evaporation can be ruled out. Chen et al. detected this phase after heating at 160–180 °C where Bi evaporation is not possible. Other authors state that this phase is a consequence of the decomposition of BiFeO3. Recently, Selbach et al. described how this secondary phase is formed at 600–800 °C by the decomposition of BFO and disappears at higher temperatures because Bi and Fe are incorporated into the structure. They rule out any effect of Bi evaporation as traces would exist at increased temperatures or even in higher amounts which was not the case. Thus, a decrease in the synthesis temperature with respect to the temperature required by the classical solid state reaction method (850–900 °C) is obtained. The lowering of the synthesis temperature is equivalent to sol–gel method values . Patterns show that initially a bismuth rich phase of BixFeyO1.5x+1.5y (x>y) composition forms at a temperature of 600 °C followed by the evolution of a BiFeO3 phase at 700 °C. Calcination between temperatures of 700–850 °C suggest that the impurity phase is completely eliminated at any of these temperatures. What is more remarkable is that the amount of the secondary phase is considerably reduced in samples synthesized by the polymeric precursor method (even at low temperatures) which appears to stem from the complexation process which induced effects in the samples and enhanced the perovskite-structured BiFeO3 formation. Fig. 1(d) shows that BFO thermally treated at 850 °C for 4 hours exhibits a pure R3c structure without any impurity. The lattice parameters calculated from XRD patterns are a=5.6206 Å and c=13.6924 Å.

AS shown in Fig. 1 , slowing down the heating rate and slow quenching to room temperature when the sample was calcined only at 400 °C for 0.5 h, led to other phases such as Bi2O3 and Fe2O3 in the diffraction patterns of BFO MNPs. These impurities indicate partially reactions occurred at this calcination temperature. The sample obtained was brown–red in color and proportions of BFO MNPs, Bi2O3 and Fe2O3 were 64%, 15% and 21%, respectively and the cell parameters for impure BFO MNPs with space group R3c were bigger than pure one (a = b = 5.589 and c = 13.894). These lattice parameters were in reasonable agreement with those reported in the literature (JCPDS 86-1518). The average crystallite size obtained from the Debye–Scherrer formula for the impure BFO MNPs was 32.86 nm.

To understand the chemical origin of the ferromagnetism in BFO, the composition of the as-prepared ferromagnetic BFO powder was determined by XPS based on the spectra of the Fe 2p core levels in terms of binding energy. As shown in Fig. 5, the BFO sample exhibits 2p core levels binding energy of 711.6 eV (Fe 2p3/2 without broaden or satellite peak) and 723.7 eV (Fe 2p1/2), corresponding to those of Fe3+ ion. No other reduced states, such as Fe2+ or Fe0, can be found in the XPS spectrum. In addition, the reactant being α-Fe2O3, it is not likely to convert into γ-Fe2O3. These XPS results suggest that the unusual ferromagnetism detected in BFO powder cannot be associated with any impurity phases, such as Fe, FeO, Fe3O4 and γ-Fe2O3, which can be excluded from the sample, but instead, it is an intrinsic property of the BiFeO3 prepared by the self-catalyzed reaction process.

Fig. 2 shows the XRD pattern and TG curve of the recycled FePO4·2H2O sample via acid leaching and reflux heating treatment. The composition and phase purity of the sample were examined by X-ray diffraction. As shown in Fig. 2a, all the diffraction peaks can be well indexed to FePO4·2H2O (JCPDS: 33-0666) without any observable impurity phase. The diffraction peaks are sharp and strong, indicating that the sample is well-crystallized.

Fig. 1 presents the XRD patterns of the LiFePO4/C composites synthesized using different ratios of Li3PO4:Li2CO3. The main phase of samples using Li2CO3 as the secondary Li source can be attributed to the orthorhombic LiFePO4 (JCPDS 81-1173, Pnma (62)) and the diffraction peaks are quite narrow and sharp. This is in accordance with the report by Yang et al. , that when an excess lithium source was used in LiFePO4 samples, no impurities were found in the XRD patterns. This suggests that the small amount of Li2CO3 has compensated the Li loss during the synthesis. However, in XRD results of samples using only Li3PO4 as the Li source (Fig. 1(a), (b) and (c)), small peaks appeared between 22–25° and 30–33°, which can be attributed to Li3PO4 and Fe2P2O7. Besides, a weak peak of Fe2P2O7 appeared around 22.2° for sample LFP1.06 (Fig. 1(c)). No carbon diffraction peaks are detected, suggesting the carbon content is too low and/or exists in amorphous form in the composites. Therefore, it is obviously advantageous to use Li2CO3 as the secondary Li source to obtain the pure LiFePO4 phase, eliminating Li3PO4. We assume that the process of LiFePO4 formation can be ascribed to the following steps: Li3PO4·0.5H2O+Fe+2FePO4·4H2O→3LiFePO4+8.5H2O

The XRD pattern of the calcined powder under both air and O annealing (Fig. 1a, b) at varying annealing temperatures between 400 and 600 °C. The XRD patterns show that the BFO peaks begin to be visible at 450 °C indicating the development of the crystalline structure. With increasing annealing temperatures the peaks grow sharper and starting from 500 °C we have a fully developed pattern indicating the pure phase perovskite structure of BFO without any detectable impurity phases such as Bi2O3 and Bi2Fe4O9. Annealing at temperatures above 600 °C leads to the development of impurity phases such as Bi2O3. Annealing in an O environment was seen to lead to better crystallinity and larger grain sizes as compared to the samples annealed in air at the same temperature (Fig. 1b). This suggests that by taking in more O, the structure of this oxide becomes better defined presumably by removing some of the O vacancies that would otherwise be present in this system.

In order to improve the crystallinity of the BFO thin film, the substrates were pre-fired at 350 °C for 5 min after each and every coating and finally annealed at 600 °C for 1 h. The XRD patterns of the pre-fired thin film (Fig. 1b) show a good agreement with JCPDS data (PDF#861518) revealing a BFO phase with a perovskite structure and belonging to the R3c space group. However, an impurity phase (Bi2Fe4O9) is also detected along with the major BFO phases due to the kinetics of formation. In order to enhance the crystallinity of BFO thin films, three samples were prepared that were annealed at 500 °C for 3, 6 and 9 h durations respectively and their XRD patterns were obtained (Fig. 2).

The synchrotron X-ray diffraction (XRD) data was employed to obtain the structural information and phase identification, the synchrotron XRD spectrum is shown in Fig. 1 (a). Observed and calculated profiles, their difference and the diffraction peak positions are also shown. Enlarged view of some major diffraction peak position in the range 4° ≤ 2θ ≤ 14°, is presented in Fig. 1(b), the inset shows the fitted result of the two principal peaks. The diffraction peak positions match well with those of rhombohedrally distorted perovskite structure with space group R3c . However minor traces (<5%) of commonly reported secondary phases of Bi2Fe4O9 and Bi25FeO40 are also present, which are often unavoidable due to complex reaction kinetics of formation of metastable BiFeO3 . The cell parameters, bond distances, and atomic positions of various atoms, extracted from Rietveld refinement of the X-ray diffraction data are presented in Table 1 . These results are comparable with reported parameters for single crystal BiFeO3 . Fig. 2 (a) shows the crystal structure of a unit cell in hexagonal symmetry; it consists of 6 Bi, 6 Fe and 18 O atoms and hence has 6 formula units of BiFeO3. Off centered displacement of Fe ions along the c-axis is observed which is about 0.397 Å = ((3.865–3.071)/2) Å. Two types of bonds (Fe–O1 and Fe–O2) with different bond length are present in FeO6 octahedron as shown in Fig. 2(b); these bond lengths are computed from the refined XRD data by executing “DISAGL” program incorporated in the GSAS software . Fe–O1 bond lengths (∼1.935 Å) are slightly shorter than Fe–O2 bond lengths (∼2.131 Å); which results in the distortion of FeO6 octahedra.

The FT-IR analysis of Bismuth ferrites (BiFeO3) nanoparticles prepared by using citric acid as a chelating agent at different calcinated temperatures has been carried out. In a case of BiFeO3 (150 °C), a broad peak in the range from 3000 to 3400 cm−1 was observed, which was attributed due to the OH stretching mode of water molecules. But as we increased the calcination temperature to 450, 550 and 650 °C, this peak was not observed due to the removal of moisture from the surface of the samples. In a case of calcination temperature of 650 °C, strong peaks discerned at 432, 525, 693 and 845 cm−1 were ascribed to the stretching and bending vibrations of Bi-O and Fe–O bonds as shown in Fig. 1. No peaks in the range from 1657 to 1699 cm−1 of symmetric bending vibration of C=O, 1390–1400 cm−1 of stretching vibration of CH of citric acid precursor and residual nitro group (NO 3−1 ) near at 1392 cm−1 obtained at 650 °C.
