But these peaks were found in the ferrites with calcination temperatures 150, 450 and 550 °C. The reason for the existence of these peaks was due to the fact that during auto combustion, a large amount of energy was released in the form of gases forming a partially crystalline form of product, consisting of organic chelating agents and metal residual precursors, respectively. So, more thermal treatment of them was needed to obtain a pure crystalline form of the material. Therefore, we calcinated them in the higher range of temperature, i.e., 450, 550 and 650 °C respectively. But with increasing the calcination temperature, i.e., up to 450 and 550 °C, the intensity of these peaks decreases. It means that with increasing temperature up to 650 °C, there was no amount of citric acid remained in the sample. We can say that during calcination at higher temperature these were released as CO2 and H2O from the reaction mixture. After this, the study was also extended to the sample calcinated at 750 °C, two new strong peaks appeared at 1058 and 806 cm−1 appeared which confirmed for the formation of more impurity phases (also cleared in Fig. 2). So, we can conclude that at calcination temperature 650 °C, only the purest form of Bismuth ferrite (BiFeO3) nanoparticles could be obtained.

The XRD pattern of LFO is in agreement with phase-pure orthorhombic LaFeO3 (JCPDS# 74-2203), whereas BFO showed reflections of rhombohedral BiFeO3 (JCPDS# 71-2494) and traces of monoclinic Bi2O3 (JCPDS# 71-465) (Fig. 1 ). The mean crystallite size was estimated using the XRD data evaluated with the Scherrer equation [24] at 60–70 nm for both perovskites. The equivalent particle diameters, calculated according to d p,equiv = 6/(SSA × ρ) with ρ as the bulk densities of the two perovskites (ρBiFeO3=8.3gcm-3 [25], ρLaFeO3=6.6gcm-3 [26]), were 210 nm and 180 nm for BFO and LFO, respectively. This indicates aggregation of the particles, which was also confirmed by the TEM images (Fig. 2 ). Aggregation phenomena during synthesis due to the high temperature calcination necessary for formation of the perovskite phase have been described before [27]. Zeta potentials determined for the two perovskites at pH = 7 revealed values around |±30| mV (see Table 1 ), which indicates incipient instability of their aqueous suspension due to low electrostatic repulsion. Table 1 summarizes the physicochemical properties of the investigated LFO and BFO catalysts.

It was found out that all reflection can be indexed to a pure rhombohedral BiFeO3 crystal phase which crystallize in R3c (no. 161) space group. However it may be seen that in representation of cell parameters and atom positions represented in Table 1, hexagonal setting have been used. Refined structure and microstructural parameters show that crystal size is in the nanometric range at about 30 nm. Reasonable values of R factors (Table 1) are an indication of good refinement and obtained results were in good agreement with previous research, where this equilibrium phase was named α- BiFeO3 structure ; ; ; ; ; ;  ;   .

Fig. 1 represents the XRD patterns of the as-prepared pure BFO, Ba-doped BFO, Cu-doped BFO and Ba-Cu co-doped BFO MNPs. All the characteristic peaks of BFO were attributed to the pure phase, JCPDS Card No.86-1518, that could be demonstrated to the BFO rhombohedral distorted structure (space group R3c). The rhombohedral structure of BFO did not show any considerable change with metal doping, but led to producing some impurity phases of Bi2Fe4O9 and Bi25FeO39 and a decrease in crystallinity.

XRD profile pattern of Bi1-xBaxFeO3 (x=0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3) samples sintered at 800 °C, is presented in Fig. 1. The diffraction pattern at x=0, can be ascribed to a rhombohedral structure of BFO having space group R3c. The two most intense peaks around 2θ ~ 32°, could be clearly observed form the diffraction pattern. The sharpness of the peaks depicted good crystallinity of the prepared BFO. The formation of minor secondary phases along with the main BFO phase can also be seen , which may be due to impurity in precursors or crucibles used for sintering the samples. The two intense peaks in BFO commence to fuse together on 10 mol% Ba ions substitution (x=0.1) in BFO. When the concentration of Ba ions was increased to 20 mol% (x=0.2), a sharp and single intense peak at 2θ=32° demonstrates the structural transformation from disorted rhombohedral (R3c) to stable pseudo-cubic (Pm3m) structure . The structural transition in Ba substituted BFO is due to the chemical pressure exerted by larger ionic radii Ba ions. It has been suggested that Ba substitution in BFO is helpful in suppressing the formation of secondary phases. At x=0.2, diffraction pattern showed the complete removal of secondary phases. However, Luo at el. reported secondary phases with 30 mol% Ba substitution in BFO. When the concentration of Ba2+ ions was increased to 30% (x=0.3), no further structural change was observed. However, a slight shift in the peak position toward lower Bragg angles indicates an increase in lattice parameter and hence the increase in lattice volume. The increase in lattice parameter on Ba substitution is due to larger ionic radius of Ba2+ ions (1.42 Å). Lattice parameters of the samples are listed in Table 1. Further, crystallite size of all samples has been calculated using the Scherrer's formula and also presented in Table 1. It is clear that the size of nanoparticles decreases with increasing Ba concentration. The decrease in the particle size on Ba substitution is ascribed to oxygen vacancies generated by the replacement of trivalent Bi3+ ion with divalent Ba2+ ion. The presence of oxygen vacancies leads to local structural modification at the domain walls. This restricts the grain boundary motion and consequently the growth of nanoparticles. The structural modification incorporated by Ba ions in BFO would also alter its magnetic and ferroelectric behavior, which is discussed in forthcoming subsections..

The XRD patterns of graphene BiFeO3 composites after being calcined at different temperatures were shown in Fig. 3b. It was found that the impurity phase of Bi2Fe4O9 (JCPDS File No. 25-0090) and Bi24Fe2O39 (JCPDS File No. 42-0201) occurred after the calcination treatment at 300 and 400 °C, respectively. Along with the poorer the crystallinity of the composite at lower temperature (below 500 °C), the existence of impurity phase will worsen the catalytic activity of the composite, which was confirmed in the degradation of TBBPA as discussed below. The crystallinity of the composite was evaluated via the relative intensity of the (1 1 0) diffraction peak (2θ = 33.11). It was hard to found the (1 1 0) diffraction peak when the calcination temperature was below 400 °C. The relative intensity of the peak was markedly increased with increasing calcination temperature from 400 to 600 °C, being indicative of increasing in the crystallinity of the composite. The XRD pattern of the composite after the calcination treatment at 600 °C showed a highly crystalline and single-phase perovskite structure (JCPDS File No. 20-169). All the peak-splitting suggests that the composite are rhombohedral, which was not significantly different from BiFeO3. There were no observable peaks of graphene in all the samples, possibly due to its low content (0.2%) in the composite. It seemed that the crystalline structure of the composite was destructed at 700 °C, which may be unfavorable to the catalytic activity of the composite. The crystallite sizes of BiFeO3 in the composites were obtained by using Scherrer equation (d=kλ/(βcosθ)), which gave the crystallites sizes as 3.15, 6.70, 15.05, 14.98 and 39.02 nm for the composites obtained with the calcination treatment at 300, 400, 500, 600 and 700 °C, respectively. It was found that the crystallites size was roughly increased with increasing calcination temperature.

Alternative to thermodynamic route using chemical pressure, kinetic controlling of rapid heating Bi2O3–Fe2O3 mixture to prevent initial formation of Bi25FeO39 and Bi2Fe4O9 and fast cooling to prevent decomposition of BiFeO3, termed as rapid liquid phase sintering technology, was also developed by Liu group and widely adapted at present to synthesize single-phased BiFeO3 ceramics. Contemporarily, suppressing formation of those secondary phases in the technology of growing BiFeO3 thin film is usually done through the control of oxygen partial pressure. Within suitable partial oxygen pressure–temperature window, those parasitic phases including Bi25FeO39 and Bi2Fe4O9 disappear while single BiFeO3 phase is obtained. Nevertheless, it is still a challenge repeatedly to obtain high resistive phase-pure BiFeO3, even using ultrapure Bi2O3 and Fe2O3 raw oxides, owing to very narrow thermodynamic window. In contrast to prepare BiFeO3, it is much convenient using chemical pressure of ternary solid solution to obtain phase-pured perovskite-structured bismuth ferrite multiferroics.

The organic precursor provides two functionalities in the synthesis process: first, a minimal amount of organic precursor is required to avoid impurity phases during firing (including Li3Fe2(PO4)3 , Li3PO4 , and Fe3O4 ), and second, the organic precursor controls the excessive particle size growth on heat-treatment (as in powder D, which has a minimal amount to ensure high phase purity albeit resulted in a 4 times larger particle size compared to powder A). Moreover, the minimal amount of organic precursor used in powder D is not expected to result in a uniform carbon coating on the larger particles. Powder B is different in that respect to powders A, C, and D because it has a high surface area and is a high phase purity powder without a carbon coating (made without the use of the organic precursor). Powder B was synthesized by modifying the pyrolysis recipe to incorporate carbon in the nanoparticles, which aided in the heat-treatment step. Thus, the carbon in powder B is rather in a loose form compared to the carbon coating in powders A, C, and D.

Fig. 2 shows the X-Ray diffraction patterns of the LFP/C-200, LFP/C-300 and LFP/C-400 composites. The XRD peaks of all of the composites demonstrate the formation of highly crystalline LiFePO4 phase with an ordered olivine structure indexed to the orthorhombic Pnma space group devoid of any detectable impurity phases. The lattice parameters for the LFP/C composites are given in Table 1 and the values of results are very close to the standard data (a=10.334 Å, b=6.010 Å, and c=4.693 Å) given by JCPDS 83-2092 . The surface morphologies of the LFP/C-200, LFP/C-300 and LFP/C-400 composites were characterized by FE-SEM and the results are shown in Fig. 3(a)–(c). The SEM images of all the composites are similar and the particles appear to have sub-micrometer or micrometer sizes with irregular shapes and severe agglomeration. The LiFePO4 particle-sizes are observed to range between 1 and 2 μm. Prosini et al. reported that particle size decreases as the amount of carbon increases by impeding the diffusion during heat-treatment. It is well known that tailoring the particle morphology in solid state synthesis is quite complicated because of the high heating temperatures, which results in irregular particle morphology and unexpected aggregation.

Additional Mössbauer spectroscopy on pristine materials (see Supporting information) indicated only a 3–5% Fe(III) content that can be assigned to a highly disordered octahedral phosphate environment close to that of Fe(III) in mineral olivine and can be a sign of a defective or amorphous ferric phase , which presence seems unavoidable unless taking drastic storage and handling precautions .

Fig. 1 shows the XRD pattern of the synthesized sample of LiFePO4. The XRD pattern of the sample prepared by this method agree very well with that of phospho-olivine LiFePO4 and no impurity phase was detected. The cyclic voltammogram of bare stainless steel (SS) mesh current collector in 2 M Li2SO4 solution was also obtained (figure not shown). The positive peak is obtained at about 2.0 V vs. SCE (corresponding to oxygen evolution) and a negative peak at about −1.0 V (corresponding to hydrogen evolution). The stable electrochemical window of water on SS mesh is about 3.0 V which is much larger than normal 1.23 V due to large over potentials. Fig. 2A shows the cyclic voltammogram of LiFePO4 in 2 M Li2SO4 solution. An oxidation peak is observed at −0.05 V during charging which corresponds to lithium de-intercalation and a reduction peak is observed at −0.63 V during discharge which corresponds to lithium ion intercalation process. The results indicate that Li+ insertion/de-insertion in LiFePO4 prepared by RAPET method is a one step process similar to those reported in literature for aqueous systems . Fig. 2B shows the cyclic voltammogram of LiFePO4 in LiAsF6/EC–DMC organic electrolyte. The peak potential difference (ΔE p) is about 1050 mV at a scan rate of 50 μV s−1. This difference in the redox peak potentials of LiFePO4 in organic electrolyte is more compared to 580 mV in aqueous 2 M Li2SO4 (Fig. 2A) measured at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1. The narrow Faradaic peaks observed in 2 M Li2SO4 compared to that in non-aqueous LiAsF6/EC–DMC electrolyte clearly indicates the fast electrochemical kinetics in aqueous electrolytes. In the present work we focus our studies only on the intercalation of Li+ ions into LiFePO4 from both the electrolytes.

The composition and phase purity of the products were examined by X-ray diffraction. The XRD patterns of the LiMPO4 sample are shown in Fig. 2. All the diffraction peaks can be indexed to the orthorhombic olivine LiMPO4 structure. No impurities are observed and the peaks are strong and narrow, indicating high crystallinity of the LiMPO4 sample. Furthermore, the compositions of LiMPO4 microstructures are confirmed by the EDS analysis of the products. As shown in Fig. S1 in the ESI,† M, P and O peaks can be readily observed, and there are no other impurity peaks in the spectra except carbon which derives from the decomposition of organic compounds. The EDS results further demonstrate the final product is pure LiMPO4.

The corresponding XRD patterns are shown in Fig. 1(a) and (b). For the solvothermal reaction, phase-pure LiFeSO4F could not be formed in 24 hours below 250 °C because of the sluggish reaction rate, while the formation of FeSO4 impurity can be observed when the temperature was too high. Similar phenomena were also observed in ionothermal syntheses, with tavorite-type LiFeSO4F only forming in a very narrow temperature range. Improper reaction settings would inevitably lead to FeSO4·H2O or FeSO4 impurity phases whose characteristic peaks are located at 23.6° and 34.1°, respectively. No Fe3+ ion was detected by Mössbauer spectroscopy, implying the high purity of the as-prepared LiFeSO4F samples. This survey shows that the best experimental condition for producing phase-pure LiFeSO4F free of Fe3+ is to heat the precursors at 230 °C for 60 hours in TTEG, or at 305 °C for 24 hours in EMI-TFSI. Such conditions were systematically used to prepare single-phase tavorite-type LiFeSO4F powders to be studied in this paper.
